questions.text: The appearance of USG at saphenofemoral junction, showing common femoral vein, common femoral artery, and the great saphenous vein is called as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mickey Mouse sign

Explanation:

  • The appearance of the ultrasound (USG) at the saphenofemoral junction, showing the common femoral vein, common femoral artery, and the great saphenous vein, is referred to as the Mickey Mouse sign.
  • In the Mickey Mouse sign, the common femoral vein represents the face of Mickey Mouse, and the common femoral artery and great saphenous vein represent the ears. This visual resemblance to the iconic Disney character gives rise to the term "Mickey Mouse sign."

 

 

Radiological Sign

Description

Associated Pathology

Classic Mickey Mouse Sign

Refers to the appearance of bilateral cranial nerve (CN) VII and CN VIII enhancement, resembling Mickey Mouse's head.

Acoustic neuroma

Reverse Mickey Mouse Sign

The reverse of the classic Mickey Mouse sign, where bilateral CN V and CN VI enhancement resemble Mickey Mouse's head.

Trigeminal schwannoma

Minnie Mouse Sign

Refers to unilateral CN VII and CN VIII enhancement, resembling Minnie Mouse's head.

Facial nerve schwannoma or hemangioma

Mickey Mouse Ears Sign

Describes bilateral globus pallidus hyperintensity on brain MRI, resembling the shape of Mickey Mouse's ears.

Wilson’s disease or Carbon monoxide poisoning

Mickey Mouse Glove Sign

Characterized by symmetric calcification of basal ganglia structures on brain CT, resembling a Mickey Mouse glove.

Fahr’s syndrome or Wilson’s disease

 

String sign (Option B): is a term used in other medical imaging modalities, such as barium studies or endoscopy, to describe a thin, elongated appearance of a narrowed or strictured segment of the gastrointestinal tract.

Tillaux sign (Option C): is a radiological finding observed in Salter-Harris III fractures of the distal tibia. It refers to the lateral displacement of the epiphysis in relation to the tibial metaphysis.

Stamers sign (Option D): Stamers sign is not a recognized medical term or radiological finding in the context of the saphenofemoral junction or ultrasound imaging.

questions.text:
Identify the heart chamber marked in the given CT image


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Left Atrium

Explanation:

  • In cardiac CT imaging, the left atrium is best visualized posteriorly, near the esophagus. It receives oxygenated blood from the pulmonary veins and is located at the posterior aspect of the heart, superior to the left ventricle.

Cardiac Chambers on CT Imaging

Chamber

Location on CT

Key Features

Right Atrium

Anterior, right side

Receives deoxygenated blood from IVC/SVC

Right Ventricle

Most anterior chamber

Lies close to the sternum, pumps blood to pulmonary artery

Left Atrium

Posterior aspect

Receives oxygenated blood from pulmonary veins

Left Ventricle

Left, inferior

Thickest-walled chamber, pumps blood into aorta

 

Right Atrium (Option A): Incorrect because it is anterior and right-sided, whereas the left atrium is posterior.

Right Ventricle (Option B): Incorrect because it is the most anterior chamber, located near the sternum.

Left Ventricle (Option C): Incorrect because it is larger and more inferior, with thick muscular walls for systemic circulation.

questions.text: In what situation is popcorn calcification observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pulmonary Hamartoma

Explanation:

  • Popcorn calcification is a characteristic finding on imaging, particularly CT scans, seen in pulmonary hamartomas. These are benign tumors of the lung, typically composed of cartilage, fat, and connective tissue. The calcifications often appear as popcorn-like due to the presence of calcified nodules or cystic components within the tumor.

Pulmonary hamartoma

  • Hamartomas are the most common benign lung tumors,
  • Generally asymptomatic and often discovered incidentally
  • Radiographic Features:
    • Typically present as a solitary peripheral pulmonary nodule or mass.
    • Size usually ranges from 1 to 4 cm.
    • Well-circumscribed, round or oval shape with smooth or lobulated margins.
    • Internal calcifications, often with a "popcorn" appearance
    • CT scans effectively reveal internal fat, which is pathognomonic for hamartomas.
  • Hamartomas may be multiple, grow slowly, and do not cavitate or invade adjacent structures.

 

Hodgkin’s lymphoma (Option A): Incorrect because Hodgkin’s lymphoma may cause mediastinal masses but does not exhibit popcorn calcifications typically. Calcifications in lymphoma are more uniform and fine.

Metastasis (Option C): Incorrect because metastatic lesions usually present as irregular nodules with variable densities. They do not typically show popcorn-like calcifications.

Fungal Ball (Option D): Incorrect because fungal balls can calcify, but these calcifications are not typically of the popcorn type. They are more likely to appear as heterogeneous or mottled calcifications.

questions.text:
Obliteration of the right cardiac border on chest X-ray indicated pathology involving which of the following structures?

[
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Right Middle Lobe

Explanation:

On a chest X-ray, the right cardiac border is formed by the right atrium. The silhouette sign helps localize pathology:

  • Obliteration of the right cardiac border occurs when a lesion in the right middle lobe is present, as the lobe lies adjacent to the right atrium.
  • The loss of normal heart-lung interface suggests consolidation, atelectasis, or mass in the right middle lobe.

Lobar Localization:

  • Lateral radiograph: Right and left upper lobe bronchi can be seen as two circular radiolucent areas with the right above the left.
  • PA view of the chest: Can locate any structure in the superoinferior dimension as well as the mediolateral dimension.
  • Silhouette sign: Locate any structure in the posteroanterior dimension.

 

  • Left Lung: Only has an oblique fissure, separating the left upper (LUL) and lower (LLL) lobes.
  • Right Lung: Oblique and horizontal fissures separate the right lung's 3 lobes.
    • Oblique fissure divides the RML and RLL.
    • Horizontal fissure divides the RUL and RML.

  

Silhouette Sign:

  • Absence of the depiction of an anatomic soft-tissue border.
  • Produced by an intrathoracic abnormality that touches the borders of the heart or aorta and obliterates those borders on the frontal chest radiograph.
  • The sign actually refers to the absence of a silhouette.
  • Silhouette sign helps localize airspace opacities, atelectasis, or masses in the lung.

 

Localization Using the Silhouette Sign

Obliterated Cardiac Border

Likely Affected Lobe

Right cardiac border (Right atrium)

Right Middle Lobe

Right hemidiaphragm

Right Lower Lobe

Left cardiac border (Left ventricle)

Lingula (Left Upper Lobe)

Left hemidiaphragm

Left Lower Lobe

Right Lower Lobe (Option A): Incorrect because pathology here would obscure the right hemidiaphragm, not the right cardiac border.

Right Atrium (Option B): Incorrect because the right atrium itself is not a lung structure; it is obscured by pathology in the adjacent right middle lobe.

Right Ventricle (Option D): Incorrect because the right ventricle is positioned more anteriorly and is not adjacent to the lung fields visualized on a standard PA chest X-ray.

questions.text: Comment on the diagnosis of CT chest shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Aortic dissection

Explanation:

  • The given CT shows an intimal tear in the aorta indicating an Aortic dissection.

 

Aortic Dissection

  • It occurs when a defect or a flap occurs in the aorta, resulting in blood tracking into aortic tissues, splitting the medial layer and creating a false lumen.

 

 

Clinical features:

  • Sudden onset of severe, tearing chest, radiating to the interscapular region
  • Renal pain and renal failure
  • Paraplegia
  • Syncope
  • Weakness
  • Hypotension or shock

 

Investigations:

  • If the patient is stable, CT angiography is the standard investigation of choice.
  • In the case of unstable patients (SBP<100 mm of HG, HR>100 bpm), the preferred investigation of choice will be TEE (TransEsophageal Echocardiography)
  • MRI can also be done if CT is unequivocal.
  • Chest x-ray reveals widening of mediastinum along with left-sided pleural effusion.

 

 

Signs of FALSE LUMEN:

  • Cobweb Sign: Irregularities of False lumen
  • Beak Sign: False lumen forms acute angle with True lumen:

 

Pulmonary embolism (Option B):

  • Filling Defect seen in Pulmonary artery
  • IOC for PE: CT Angiography

 

Cardiac Myxoma (Option C):

  • Low annotating hypodense lesion on the posterior most chamber of the heart (Left Atrium)
  • MC primary Benign cardiac tumor in adults.

 

Aortic aneurysm (Option D):

  • Involve either ascending aorta, thoracic aorta & abdominal aorta
  • Represents localized dilation of the aorta; while an aneurysm may predispose to dissection, an intimal tear specifically indicates dissection.
  • M/C cause for abdominal & thoracic aortic aneurysm: Atherosclerosis

questions.text: A 55 year old male patient presented with complaints of dyspnea with congestive heart failure. The clinician wants to know whether it's HF with preserved EF or reduced EF. Which of the below investigation is used for calculation of ejection fraction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) MUGA

Explanation:

  • Ejection fraction (EF) is a critical parameter for differentiating heart failure with preserved EF (HFpEF) from heart failure with reduced EF (HFrEF).
  • MUGA scan is a non-invasive nuclear imaging test that accurately calculates EF by analyzing the motion of the heart's ventricles using a radioactive tracer and a gamma camera.

 

Purpose

Scan types

For Myocardial Perfusion

  • Assess ischemia
  • Cold spot: decreased uptake in ischemic areas.
  • Thallium scan (Commonly used) (Option B)
  • Tetrofosmin
  • Sestamibi scan (Option D)

For Myocardial Infarction

  • Assess infarct
  • Hot spot in infarct area as pyrophosphate accumulates and is not metabolized.
  • 99m Tc - Pyrophosphate scan.

For Ventricular Function

  • Evaluate ejection fraction
  • MUGA (Multiple Gated Acquisition) scan (AKA nuclear ventriculography)
    • Radiolabeled RBCs are used
  • Most accurate for ventricular function - Cardiac MRI

For Myocardial Viability

 
  • Assess the viability of myocardium
  • PETscan - Best investigation for myocardial viability. (Option C)
    • Perfusion and metabolism mismatch are observed in the PET scan.
    • Perfusion Agents:N-13 ammonia and Rubidium chloride.
    • Metabolism Agent: FDG-PET is used for glucose metabolism.
      • No FDG uptake indicates a normal heart or an infarct.
      • FDG uptake is present: In the Ischemic Myocardium
    • FDG-PET is combined with perfusion imaging for comprehensive assessment.
      • Uptake in PET with low perfusion indicates reversible dysfunction (suggestive of hibernation).
      • Irreversible dysfunction indicates the presence of scar tissue.
    • Note: Hibernating myocardium is ischemic but viable.

 

Myocardial Viability

questions.text: Which of the following statements is accurate concerning CORADS? CORADS: COVID-19 Reporting and Data System

choices.text: Pleural thickening is typical of COVID-19
Lobar consolidation is typical of COVID-19

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CORADS-5 is typical of COVID- 19

Explanation:

  • The COVID-19 Reporting and Data System (CORADS) is a standardized system for assessing the probability of COVID-19 pneumonia based on CT findings. CORADS-5 indicates a very high level of suspicion for COVID-19, with features such as bilateral ground-glass opacities, crazy paving patterns, and subpleural involvement—typical imaging findings in COVID-19 pneumonia.

 

CO-RADS (COVID-19 Reporting and Data System):

Aspect

Details

Purpose

Categorical assessment of chest CT scans for suspected COVID-19 cases

Scale

CO-RADS 1 (very low suspicion) to CO-RADS 5 (very high suspicion)

Interobserver Agreement

Moderate to substantial agreement among radiologists

Discriminatory Power

High accuracy in diagnosing COVID-19

Utility & Reliability

Effective and standardized reporting tool

CO-RADS-AI

AI-based tool that automates CO-RADS scoring and CT severity assessment

Accuracy

Effective in high-prevalence areas

Combination with Other Findings

AUC value of 0.89 when used with RT-PCR and clinical findings

 

CORADS-0 indicates normal lung (option A): This is incorrect because CORADS-0 is used when the scan is technically insufficient or of poor quality, and not for a normal lung.\

Pleural thickening is typical of COVID-19 (option C): This is incorrect because pleural thickening is not a typical finding in COVID-19 pneumonia; it is more common in chronic lung diseases or other infections.

Lobar consolidation is typical of COVID-19 (option D): This is incorrect because lobar consolidation is more typical of bacterial pneumonia, whereas COVID-19 pneumonia usually shows patchy ground-glass opacities and consolidation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with Marfanoid features presented with a sudden onset of breathlessness. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Pneumothorax

Explanation:

A 25-year-old male with Marfanoid features presenting with sudden-onset breathlessness strongly suggests spontaneous pneumothorax, which is commonly seen in Marfan syndrome due to underlying connective tissue defects.

  • Radiological Features (Chest X-ray):
    • Absent lung markings in the affected area
    • Hyperlucency due to air accumulation
    • Collapsed lung margin
    • Mediastinal shift (in tension pneumothorax)

The classic association of Marfan syndrome with spontaneous pneumothorax makes this the most likely diagnosis.

Spontaneous Pneumothorax

  • Spontaneous pneumothorax occurs when air enters the pleural space without trauma. It is classified into:

Type

Features

Primary

No underlying lung disease, seen in tall, thin males (e.g., Marfan syndrome)

Secondary

Occurs in patients with underlying lung disease (e.g., COPD, tuberculosis)

Tension Pneumothorax

Air trapping leads to mediastinal shift, requiring emergency intervention
  • Diagnosis: Confirmed by chest X-ray or CT scan.
  • Management: Needle decompression for tension pneumothorax, followed by chest tube insertion for drainage.

Radiological findings in pneumothorax

  • Visible visceral pleural edge as a thin white line.
  • Absent lung markings peripheral to this line.
  • The affected side is radiolucent compared to the opposite side.
  • Collapsed lung on the affected side.

Contralateral mediastinal shift especially in massive pneumothoraces (tension pneumothorax).

The diaphragm of the affected side is pushed down.
  • The supine radiograph shows the deep sulcus sign.
  • It shows a deep costophrenic angle extending towards the hypochondrium.

Incorrect Options:

Pleural effusion (Option B):

  • Incorrect because pleural effusion presents with blunting of the costophrenic angle and meniscus sign, not hyperlucency.

Consolidation (Option C):

  • Incorrect because consolidation appears as opacification with air bronchograms, whereas pneumothorax shows increased radiolucency.

Fibrosis (Option D):

  • Incorrect because fibrosis presents with reticulonodular opacities and volume loss, not hyperlucency or lung collapse.

questions.text: A 47-year-old diabetic patient presents with fever, malaise, and productive cough. Which of the following is an incorrect statement?

choices.text: Patchy infiltrates are seen in pyogenic pneumonia
Interstitial infiltrates are seen in Mycoplasma pneumonia
Hilar lymphadenopathy with lung infiltrates is seen in malignancy
Aspiration pneumonia is more common in the posterior segment of the upper lobes and superior segment of the lower lobes

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Patchy infiltrates are seen in pyogenic pneumonia
 

Explanation:

  • The most common cause of community-acquired pyogenic pneumonia is Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus).
  • The most common imaging pattern seen on a chest X-ray for pneumococcal pneumonia is lobar consolidation; meaning a homogeneous consolidation affecting one or more lobes of the lung
  • Patchy infiltrates are not typical for pyogenic pneumonia caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Classification of Pneumonia Based on Imaging Pattern:

  1. Lobar Pneumonia:
    • Unifocal consolidation, most commonly caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae.
    • In children under 8 years, may appear as “Round Pneumonia” with ill-defined margins.
    • Air bronchograms are common due to patent airways and minimal volume loss.
  2. Bronchopneumonia (Lobular Pneumonia):
    • Multifocal distribution, centered around distal airways.
    • Heterogeneous scattered opacities along airway course, coalescing in severe cases.
    • Air bronchogram absent due to airway involvement.
  3. Atypical Pneumonia:
    • Features distinct from lobar or bronchopneumonia (discussed in the table below).

 

Causative Agent

Specific Imaging Features

Streptococcus pneumoniae

Most common cause of community-acquired lobar pneumonia in adults.

Staphylococcus aureus
  • Common in debilitated patients / superinfection in influenza / secondary to IV drug abuse.
  • Cavitation common in later radiographs.
  • Pneumatoceles (seen in children during recovery phase).

Klebsiella pneumoniae
  • Occurs in elderly and alcoholics, usually involves the right upper lobe (RUL).
  • Bulging of fissures due to increased involved lung volume.

Legionnaire’s disease (Legionella pneumophila)
  • Rapidly spreading pneumonia from contaminated water sources (ACs, coolers, showers).
  • Also presents with diarrhea, mental confusion (hyponatremia), and shock.

Actinomycosis
  • Can mimic bronchogenic carcinoma.
  • Soft tissue/bone involvement (periostitis) – key differentiating feature.
  • CT: Peripheral homogeneous consolidation with central low attenuation and pleural thickening (diagnostic feature).

Atypical pneumonia (Most common cause: Mycoplasma pneumoniae)
  • Atypical organism (lacks cell walls, resistant to penicillins).
  • Fine reticular/nodular shadows in perihilar region early, which may progress to consolidation (rare lobar involvement).
  • WBC count usually normal.
  • Presents with non-productive cough, absent/minimal sputum.
  • Not aspiration-related.
  • Common in poorly maintained air-conditioned areas.
  • Other viral causes: Influenza A & B, RSV, Adenovirus, Chlamydia psittaci, Coxiella burnetii (Q fever).

Varicella pneumonia
  • Predominantly nodular opacities (5–10 mm).
  • If persistent, may calcify, leading to miliary shadows on CXR.

 

Interstitial infiltrates are seen in Mycoplasma pneumonia (Option B):

  • Mycoplasma pneumonia typically causes atypical pneumonia, with interstitial infiltrates rather than lobar consolidation.

Hilar lymphadenopathy with lung infiltrates is seen in malignancy (Option C):

  • Lung cancer, especially small cell carcinoma and lymphoma, commonly presents with hilar lymphadenopathy along with parenchymal lung infiltrates.

Aspiration pneumonia is more common in the posterior segment of the upper lobes and superior segment of the lower lobes (Option D):

  • Aspiration pneumonia classically affects the dependent lung segments, particularly the posterior segment of the upper lobes and the superior segment of the lower lobes, especially in supine patients.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with hypertension, chest pain, and cramping of the legs. A chest radiograph was taken which revealed the condition as shown in the image below. What is the likely cause of hypertension in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Coarctation of aorta

Explanation:

  • The presence of the Figure of 3 sign and rib notching on X-ray, along with symptoms of hypertension and chest pain, indicates coarctation of the aorta. These findings suggest narrowed aorta leading to collateral circulation and rib erosion, confirming the diagnosis.
  • Figure of 3 sign: This sign indicates a contour abnormality of the aorta commonly associated with coarctation of the aorta. It is characterized by a distinctive "3" shape formed by the aorta and adjacent structures on the X-ray.

Inferior rib notching:

 

Radiographic Features of Coarctation of the Aorta (CoA)

Plain Radiograph Findings

  • Figure of 3 Sign
    • Contour abnormality of the aorta, indicative of coarctation.
  • Inferior Rib Notching (Roesler Sign)
    • Erosion of the inferior margins of ribs (usually 4th–8th) by dilated intercostal collateral vessels.
    • Seen in long-standing cases (70% of older children/adults).
    • Rare in infancy or children <5 years.
  • Collateral Pathways
    • Increased subclavian artery flow promotes collateral formation via:
      • Internal thoracic arteries
      • Anterior and posterior intercostal arteries
  • Rib Notching Patterns
    • Bilateral Rib Notching:
      • Coarctation distal to both subclavian arteries.
    • Unilateral Right Rib Notching:
      • Coarctation between the brachiocephalic trunk and left subclavian artery, or
      • Right-sided aortic arch with an aberrant left subclavian artery.
    • Unilateral Left Rib Notching:
      • Aberrant right subclavian artery arising post-coarctation, with collaterals on the left.

 

Essential hypertension (Option B): refers to high blood pressure without a known underlying cause. It is typically a diagnosis of exclusion, meaning other identifiable causes of hypertension should be ruled out. In this case, the chest radiograph findings strongly suggest a specific underlying cause rather than essential hypertension.

Aortic aneurysm (Option C): refers to a localized dilation or ballooning of the aorta. While it can lead to hypertension in some cases, the characteristic radiographic finding for aortic aneurysm would be an enlarged, bulging segment of the aorta rather than rib notching.

Aorta-arteritis (Option D): Aorta-arteritis, such as Takayasu arteritis, refers to inflammation and narrowing of the large arteries, including the aorta. While it can cause hypertension, the specific radiographic finding associated with aorta-arteritis would be wall thickening or narrowing of the involved vessels rather than rib notching.

questions.text: Plethoric lung fields are seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) TAPVC

Explanation:

  • Plethoric lung fields are seen on chest X-ray when there is increased pulmonary blood flow.
  • In TAPVC, pulmonary veins connect abnormally to the systemic venous circulation instead of the left atrium. This results in mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood, leading to increased pulmonary blood flow and congestion.

Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC)

Pathology
  • Pulmonary veins drain into the right atrium directly or indirectly via an abnormal venous connection
  • Not a ductal-dependent cyanotic lesion

Sites of venous connection
  • Supracardiac- superior vena cava (Most common)
  • Cardiac-coronary sinus, right atrium
  • Infracardiac
  • Mixed

Clinical presentation
  • Cyanosis and congestive cardiac failure
  • With ASD- wide and split S2

Chest X-ray
  • Snowman or figure-8 configuration in supracardiac TAPVC

Treatment
  • Surgery
  • No indication for prostaglandins (Not a ductal-dependent cyanotic lesion)

Incorrect Options:

Tricuspid atresia (Option B): is a congenital heart defect where the tricuspid valve is completely closed or absent. It leads to cyanosis and reduced pulmonary blood flow, which is typically associated with diminished pulmonary vascular markings rather than plethoric lung fields.

Ebstein anomaly (Option C): is a rare congenital heart defect characterized by abnormal tricuspid valve anatomy. It results in a displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets into the right ventricle, causing right atrial enlargement. Plethoric lung fields are not a characteristic radiological finding associated with this condition.

TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot) (Option D): TOF is a congenital heart defect characterized by four specific abnormalities in the heart's structure. It includes a ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. While TOF can result in a right-to-left shunt and cyanosis, it typically leads to reduced pulmonary blood flow and diminished pulmonary vascular markings rather than plethoric lung fields.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 36-year-old farmer who presented with a cough, chest pain lasting one week, fatigue persisting for a month, and a chest x-ray revealing the image provided below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hydatid cyst

Explanation:

The image shows ‘Water lily sign’ (partially fluid-filled cyst with a floating endocyst) seen in hydatid cyst.

Hydatid cyst

Echinococcus granulosus (most common), E. multilocularis, and E. vogeli.

Cause cystic lesions primarily in the liver and lungs.

Dogs are the primary reservoir; mammals serve as intermediate hosts.

Unilocular Cystic Echinococcosis (E. granulosus):

  • Pulmonary Involvement Can occur through diaphragm invasion or hematogenous spread.
  • Lungs are the second most common site for hematogenous spread in adults and the primary site in children.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • Uncomplicated cysts appear as thin-walled, round or oval masses with low-attenuation contents and a thin enhancing wall, up to 10 cm in size.
  • Signs of Impending Rupture:
  • Meniscus Sign: Air lucency between the pericyst and laminated membranes when cyst communicates with bronchioles.
  • Signs Associated with Cyst Rupture:
  • Cumbo Sign or Onion Peel Sign:
    • Indicates that the endocyst has shrunk and ruptured due to increasing air.
    • Curvilinear membrane outlined by air both inside the endocyst and a crescent of air between the endocyst and pericyst.
    • Water Lily Sign:
      • Also known as the camalote sign.
      • Indicates that the endocyst membrane is detached, it will appear as a floating curvilinear structure ( fluid-filled cyst ) within an intact pericyst.
      • This gives the appearance of a floating water lily.
  • Mass Within the Cavity: An endocyst floating in a completely fluid-filled cyst.
  • Other Radiographic and CT Findings:
    • Possible pleural effusion, elevated hemidiaphragm, consolidation, basilar atelectasis, pleural cavity cysts, and superadded infections leading to empyema.

Anthrax (Option B) is an infection caused by gram-positive, rod-shaped bacteria known as Bacillus Anthracis.It commonly affects domestic or wild animals. Animals become infected when they breathe or ingest contaminated soil, plants, or water. Humans become infected when they inhale spores or eat food contaminated with spores. Inhalation Anthrax is associated with pleural effusions and mediastinal widening

Silicosis (Option C) is a chronic disease caused by inhaling large amounts of crystalline silica dust for many years. In chest radiography, it appears as small and large with irregular opacities, bilaterally symmetrical: commonly in the middle lung zone or peripheral ⅓ of the lung.

Byssinosis (Option D) is a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis that can result from exposure to cotton fibers. Chest x-ray examination may show hyper translucency, diaphragm flattening, and emphysema. Ill-defined haziness can be seen in lower lung fields.

questions.text: The structure marked with arrowhead is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Trachea

Explanation:

  • The arrowhead in the X-ray points to a midline, air-filled tubular structure. Based on the image, the structure is most consistent with the trachea.

Normal Chest X Rays with marking:

Incorrect Options:

Esophagus (Option A):

  • The esophagus is posterior to the trachea
  • It does not appear as a dark, air-filled structure like the trachea in this image.

Pulmonary artery (Option B):

  • The pulmonary arteries are part of the hilar structures in the lungs. They are located lateral to the trachea and do not appear as a straight, air-filled structure on a chest X-ray.

Left atrium (Option D):

  • The left atrium is part of the heart and is located in the lower part of the mediastinum. It is not a tubular structure and cannot appear as an air-filled space.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints with dyspnoea. The shown X-ray is suggestive of:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Exudative pleural effusion

Explanation:

  • Based on the description provided, the X-ray findings include obliteration of the costophrenic angle (CP angle) and an upward concave curve on the left side of the lung.
    • These findings are suggestive of a pleural effusion.

Pleural Effusion:

  • Pleural effusion is the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space.
  • Small Pleural Fluid: Often undetectable on PA chest x-rays; ultrasound or CT can detect small subpulmonary effusions.
  • Effusion Progression: Blunting of costophrenic angles starts at 200-500 mL. Classic signs include opacification of the lower chest with a concave superior margin.
  • Massive Effusions: 1000 mL reaches the fourth anterior rib; cause dense opacification of the hemithorax with contralateral mediastinal shift. Diaphragmatic inversion may occur.
  • Lateral decubitus X-rays: Increase sensitivity for small effusions as the pleural fluid moves with gravity and the lung effectively floats on the effusion.
  • Subpulmonary Effusions: Appear as a "high hemidiaphragm" on x-rays, with an unusual contour that peaks laterally than usual. Ultrasound or CT confirms the diagnosis.
  • In an upright PA view, the meniscus sign indicates the presence of a significant amount of pleural fluid, typically exceeding 200 mL and blunting the costophrenic angle.

 

  • Loculated (encysted, encapsulated) pleural fluid:
    • Fluid can loculate between visceral pleural layers in fissures or between visceral and parietal layers, often against the chest wall.
    • Commonly results from adhesions.
    • Xray shows D sign.

 

Consolidation (Option A): This would show more distinct lung tissue involvement with air bronchograms and possible increased density, but it wouldn’t obliterate the costophrenic angle as seen in pleural effusion.

Pneumothorax (Option C) shows a region of lucency (darkness) along the lung margin, typically more pronounced on an erect chest X-ray. In this case symptoms of pleural effusion and x-ray findings suggest fluid rather than air, making pneumothorax unlikely.

Hydropneumothorax (Option D) indicates the presence of both air and fluid in the pleural space, typically seen as an air-fluid level on upright chest X-ray, which distinguishes it from a simple pleural effusion.

questions.text:
Identify the sign:



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Seashore sign

Explanation:

  • The Seashore sign is an M ultrasound sign where pleural and structures above appear as horizontal echogenic (bright) lines, while the underlying lung shows a grainy or sandy texture, which represents lung sliding.
  • This is commonly seen in normal lungs with adequate ventilation, differentiating lung sliding from pneumothorax where lung sliding is absent.

Sea-shore sign:

  • On M-mode images, lung sliding manifests as the sea-shore sign, where the pleura and structures above appear as horizontal echogenic lines.
  • The underlying lung presents a grainy or sandy texture.
  • The stratified appearance above the pleural line is due to the motionless chest wall, resembling sea waves, while below the pleural line, the lung movement creates a sandy pattern, akin to the shore.

Barcode/stratosphere sign: (Option B, C)

  • In cases where lung sliding is absent, M-mode images show uniform horizontal straight lines known as the stratosphere sign or barcode sign.
  • The lack of a grainy or sandy appearance in these images indicates the absence of motion.
  • The stratosphere sign suggests that pneumothorax may be a likely cause.

Lung point sign:

  • The border between the sliding lung and pneumothorax is referred to as the "lung point" sign.
  • This sign can assist in estimating the size of the pneumothorax.
  • It is important to note that the lung point is only observable if part of the lung is still in contact with the chest wall.
  • The lung point sign is not present in large pneumothoraces.

 

 

Deep sulcus sign (Option D): An X-ray sign where the costophrenic angle appears deepened in pneumothorax

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented with a productive cough. He is a chronic smoker and alcoholic. CXR is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Consolidation
 

Explanation:

  • Consolidation refers to a condition in which the air spaces in the lungs fill with fluid, inflammatory exudates, or cellular infiltrates, leading to the loss of normal air-filled lung tissue.
  • On chest X-ray (CXR), consolidation appears as an area of increased opacity due to the filling of alveoli with fluid, pus, or other substances.
  • In this case, the patient's chronic smoking and alcoholism increase the risk of developing respiratory infections.

 

 

CXR Radiological Findings

Associated Diseases

Consolidation

Pneumonia, Lung abscess

Infiltrates

Pulmonary edema, ARDS

Atelectasis

Obstructive lung disease, Pneumothorax

Blunting of the Costophrenic Angle

Pleural effusion, Empyema

Cavity

Tuberculosis, Lung abscess

Nodule/mass

Lung cancer, Pulmonary metastasis

Ground-glass opacities

Interstitial lung diseases (e.g., Pulmonary fibrosis, Pneumoconiosis)

Honeycombing

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, End-stage interstitial lung disease

Air bronchograms

Consolidation, Alveolar processes

Mediastinal shift

Pneumothorax, Large pleural effusion, Mediastinal mass

 

 

Abscess (Option A): They would typically appear as a cavity with an air-fluid level, which is not mentioned here.

Cavity filled with air & fluid

Cavity (Option C): Cavities have distinct air-fluid levels and thin or thick walls, seen in tuberculosis.

Pleural effusion (Option D): This would present with obliteration of the costophrenic angle and/or meniscus sign, not described in this case.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and cough with expectoration. The chest X-ray has been shown below. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Pneumococcus

Explanation:

  • The chest X-ray showed features of round pneumonia and the patient presented with fever and cough with expectoration, the likely causative organism is Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • Round pneumonia is a term used to describe a specific radiographic appearance of pneumonia caused by Streptococcus pneumonia.

Disease

Radiological Findings

Staphylococcal Pneumonia (Option D)

Air Bronchogram

Mycoplasma Pneumonia

Reticulonodular Markings

Klebsiella Pneumonia

Bulging Fissure Sign

Legionella Pneumonia

Bilateral Multifocal Consolidation

Pneumocystis carinii Pneumonia

Reticular Shadows and multiple cysts more often in the upper part of the lungs.

Lung Abscess

Air-Fluid Level

Aspergilloma

Fungal ball/ Monad sign

Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis

Gloved-Finger Sign

Invasive Aspergillosis

Air-Crescent Sign/ Halo sign

Adenoid Hypertrophy

Adenoid Enlargement

Acute Epiglottitis

Thumb Sign

Croup (Parainfluenza) (Option B)

Steeple Sign

Mucormycosis

Reverse halo sign/Bird nest sign/Atoll sign

Haemophilus influenzae (Option A)

Patchy or segmental consolidation, may have pleural effusion

questions.text: The given USG of lung shows:
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option is B. Sea shore sign.

The Sea shore sign is seen on ultrasound imaging of the lung. It refers to the appearance of a wavy, irregular border between the aerated lung and the fluid-filled or consolidated lung tissue. This sign is observed in the context of pulmonary edema or consolidation.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Stratosphere sign: This is not a recognized sign in lung ultrasound imaging.

  • Also known as barcode sign.
  • If lung sliding is absent, it will appear on the M-mode images as uniform horizontal straight lines known as the stratosphere sign or the barcode sign

Option C. Troposphere sign: This is not a recognized sign in lung ultrasound imaging.

  • There is nothing like that

Option D. Mirror image artifact: This refers to an artifact where a structure appears duplicated or mirrored in the ultrasound image, and it is not specific to lung imaging.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the chest X-ray of a sand mine worker. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Silicosis

Explanation:

  • Silicosis is a pneumoconiosis caused by chronic inhalation of crystalline silica dust, common in occupations such as sand mining, stone cutting, and quarrying.
  • Inhaled silica particles are phagocytosed by alveolar macrophages, leading to their death and the release of inflammatory mediators, which stimulate fibroblast proliferation and collagen deposition, resulting in progressive pulmonary fibrosis.
  • On chest X-ray, the hallmark finding is "eggshell calcification" — a thin rim of calcification along the periphery of enlarged hilar lymph nodes.
  • Parenchymal findings often include small rounded opacities (upper lobe–predominant nodules) that may coalesce over time, forming progressive massive fibrosis.

Incorrect Options:

Sarcoidosis (Option A): Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy without eggshell calcification; may show parenchymal reticulonodular pattern.

Tuberculosis (Option B): Can complicate silicosis (“silicotuberculosis”), but primary TB shows consolidation, cavitation, or miliary nodules, not classic eggshell calcification.

Asbestosis (Option D): Lower lobe–predominant interstitial fibrosis with pleural plaques (often calcified), not hilar lymph node eggshell calcification.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis based on the image provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) RUL collapse

Explanation: The image shows a tracheal shift towards the right side, which indicates volume loss in the right lung.

  • Right upper lobe (RUL) collapse causes ipsilateral mediastinal shift, elevation of the horizontal fissure, and crowding of ribs.
  • Collapse (atelectasis) results in a "pull" effect, drawing the trachea towards the affected side - unlike a mass or effusion, which usually pushes it away.

RUL consolidation (Option B): No significant volume loss, so trachea usually remains central or shifts away slightly if there is a large mass effect.

Bronchogenic carcinoma (Option C): May cause collapse if obstructing bronchus, but the primary radiological sign here is collapse itself, not the mass.

Lung abscess (Option D): Produces a cavity with air-fluid level but does not typically cause significant tracheal shift toward the lesion unless there is secondary collapse.

questions.text:
Which of the following findings are seen in a high-resolution CT scan of fungal pneumonia?

1. Interlobular septations

2. Peripheral wedge-shaped consolidation

3. Pleural effusion

4. Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities
questions.solution:
Answer: A) 1,2,4

 

Explanation:

Interlobular septations (1): Fungal pneumonia can cause thickening of interlobular septa due to inflammation or oedema, particularly in invasive fungal infections like mucormycosis or aspergillosis.

Peripheral wedge-shaped consolidation (2): A hallmark of angioinvasive fungal infections (e.g., Aspergillus) is peripheral, wedge-shaped areas of consolidation due to vascular infarction.

Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground-glass opacities (4): Known as the "halo sign," this finding is common in invasive aspergillosis, where necrosis leads to cavitation surrounded by haemorrhage.

 

Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA)

• ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction affecting the major upper lobe airways leading to upper lobe bronchiectasis.

• It is associated with Elevated serum IgE levels, Positive serum precipitins for Aspergillus, Respiratory symptoms similar to asthma, Skin reactivity to Aspergillus

 

Radiographic Findings:

• Non-segmental opacities primarily in the upper lobes

• Lobar collapse

• Branching thick tubular opacities due to mucus and fungus (known as the "finger-in-glove sign" or "Y" shape)

• Occasional pulmonary cavitation

Aspergillus Mycetomas/ Aspergilloma/ Fungal Ball

 

• Aspergillus mycetomas are saprophytic growths that inhabit preexisting lung cavities, 

• These are predominantly found in the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes.

 

CT Characteristics:

• Appears as a mass with soft-tissue attenuation within a lung cavity.

• The mass is usually separated from the cavity wall by an airspace, known as the "Air crescent" or Monod sign.

• The position of the mass may change between prone and supine orientations, demonstrating its mobility.

Angioinvasive Aspergillosis

 

• Primarily occurs in immunocompromised individuals, 

◦ Involves invasion and blockage of small to medium pulmonary arteries.

◦ Leads to the formation of necrotic hemorrhagic nodules or infarcts.

 

CT Findings:

• Commonly presented as multiple nodules surrounded by a halo of ground-glass attenuation "halo sign" or pleural-based wedge-shaped consolidations. 

• The bronchial cut-off sign indicates central necrosis.

• Nodular opacities tend to be widespread across several lung lobes, unlike the clustered peribronchial opacities seen in bacterial infections.

 

Pleural effusion (3): This is uncommon in fungal pneumonia and is not a typical feature. It is more often associated with bacterial pneumonia or empyema.

questions.text: A patient with a history of breast cancer underwent Cobalt-60 radiotherapy. She now presents with respiratory distress, and imaging shows haziness in the left lung. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• History of Cobalt-60 Radiotherapy:
    • The patient has undergone radiotherapy for breast cancer, which is a known risk factor for radiation pneumonitis.
  • Symptoms of Respiratory Distress:
    • Radiation pneumonitis typically presents weeks to months after radiotherapy with dyspnea, dry cough, and low-grade fever.
  • Imaging Findings (Haziness in Left Lung):
    • Chest X-ray or CT often shows hazy opacities in the irradiated lung field, which is characteristic of radiation-induced lung injury.

Radiation Pneumonitis

Feature

Details

Cause

Radiation damage to lung tissue, commonly from breast, lung, or esophageal cancer radiotherapy

Onset

4-12 weeks post-radiotherapy

Symptoms

Dry cough, dyspnea, low-grade fever, chest pain

Imaging

Hazy opacities in the irradiated lung field (CT: ground-glass opacities, consolidation)

Treatment

Corticosteroids (prednisone), supportive care

Recurrence of Breast Cancer (Option B): Incorrect because recurrence usually presents with lung nodules or pleural effusion, not diffuse haziness.

Pulmonary Embolism (Option C): Incorrect because PE typically presents with sudden pleuritic chest pain, clear lung fields on X-ray, and wedge-shaped infarcts on CT pulmonary angiography.

Infective Pneumonia (Option D): Incorrect because pneumonia usually presents with fever, productive cough, and lobar consolidation, whereas radiation pneumonitis causes non-infective lung inflammation.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The provided chest X-ray appears to show bilateral diffuse alveolar opacities, which are characteristic of pulmonary edema.

  1. Diffuse bilateral infiltrates in a butterfly or bat-wing pattern are seen, which suggests pulmonary edema.
  2. Engorgement of pulmonary vessels and Kerley B lines (septal lines) are often present.
  3. The presence of a central distribution of opacities sparing the periphery is highly suggestive.
  4. Cardiogenic pulmonary oedema often shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette, indicating heart failure as the underlying cause.

Pulmonary Edema

Feature

Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema

Non-Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema

Cause

Left heart failure, volume overload

ARDS, infections, sepsis, toxins

X-ray Findings

A-Alveolar oedema (Bat wings)

B-Kerley B lines

C-Cardiomegaly

D-Dilated Upper lobe vessels

E-Pleural Effusion

Diffuse alveolar infiltrates, normal heart size

Symptoms

Dyspnea, orthopnea, pink frothy sputum

Severe hypoxia, respiratory distress

Treatment

Diuretics, nitrates, and oxygen treat CHF

Oxygen, and ventilatory support, treat the underlying cause

 

Xray findings of Cardiogenic pulmonary edema:

Chest X-ray showing Batwing appearance due to Alveolar edema

 

Chest X-ray showing Kerley B lines, Cardiomegaly, Dilated vessels of upper lobe and mild pleural effusion.

Hydrothorax (Option B): Incorrect because hydrothorax refers to fluid in the pleural space (pleural effusion due to CHF, liver disease), which appears as a blunted costophrenic angle and fluid meniscus, not diffuse infiltrates.

Pleural Effusion (Option C): Incorrect because pleural effusion appears as homogeneous opacity with meniscus sign rather than diffuse alveolar opacities.

Pulmonary Fibrosis (Option D): Incorrect because pulmonary fibrosis presents as reticular opacities, honeycombing, and reduced lung volumes, unlike the alveolar pattern seen here.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents with chest pain and hoarseness of voice for the past month. Based on the radiographic image provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Saccular aneurysm of the distal arch
Dissecting aneurysm of the arch of the aorta

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Saccular aneurysm of the distal arch:

  • The clinical presentation and radiographic findings of a localized outpouching on the aorta are consistent with a saccular aneurysm of the aortic arch. The patient presents with chest pain and hoarseness of voice, which suggests the involvement of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve—a phenomenon known as Cardiovocal Syndrome (Ortner syndrome).

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness that improves with rest. She also complains of dysphagia and has engorged veins in her thorax. Based on the CT scan image provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Thymoma:

  • Thymomas are the most common neoplasm of the thymus gland and typically present as anterior mediastinal mass. Myasthenia gravis is commonly associated with thymomas. Dysphagia and engorged thoracic veins suggest compression of the esophagus and superior vena cava. The CT also shows an anterior mediastinal mass, which supports the diagnosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not associated with the given findings.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with respiratory distress and a history of recurrent respiratory infections. Based on the radiographs provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Congenital pulmonary airway malformation:

  • The echogenic appearance of the lungs on antenatal ultrasound and multiple cysts in the CT scan and X-ray are suggestive of CPAM.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lung abscess: A lung abscess typically appears on imaging as a thick-walled cavity within the lung, often containing an air-fluid level.

Option C – Pyopneumothorax: Pyopneumothorax will show an air-fluid level, and loss of silhouette with the dome of the diaphragm may be seen.

Option D - Congenital diaphragmatic hernia: CDH occurs when abdominal organs herniate into the thoracic cavity due to a defect in the diaphragm.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with acute epigastric pain and elevated serum lipase. He was stabilized after three days. What is the most common pathology associated with the chest X-ray obtained?
questions.solution:
Correction Answer: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)

Explanation:

  • The patient has acute pancreatitis (suggested by epigastric pain + elevated serum lipase).

  • ARDS is a known pulmonary complication of acute pancreatitis, especially in severe cases due to inflammatory cytokine release.

  • ARDS typically develops within a few days of the primary illness and can be seen on chest X-ray as bilateral diffuse alveolar infiltrates without cardiomegaly.

Abdominal Pathology Causing Pulmonary Complications

Condition Primary Event Lung Complication Time of Onset Imaging Finding
Acute pancreatitis Inflammation, enzyme release ARDS Within 24–72 hours Bilateral infiltrates (non-cardiogenic)
Heart failure Volume overload Pulmonary edema Variable Bilateral perihilar haziness + cardiomegaly
Pulmonary embolism Thrombus in pulmonary arteries Infarcts, pleural-based opacities Sudden onset Wedge-shaped infarcts on CXR/CT
Miliary TB Disseminated TB infection Miliary nodules throughout lung Subacute/chronic Uniform millet-sized nodules

 

Acute pulmonary edema (Option B):
Incorrect because this usually shows perihilar bat-wing pattern and is associated with cardiac causes, which are not suggested here.

Pulmonary thromboembolism (Option C):
Incorrect as there is no sudden-onset dyspnea, chest pain, or risk factors for DVT/PE; and CT chest is usually needed, not just CXR.

Miliary TB (Option D):
Incorrect because miliary TB is chronic, not acute, and has constitutional symptoms (fever, weight loss); not consistent with acute pancreatitis history.

questions.text: A patient presents with foul-smelling sputum, breathlessness, and fever. Based on the X-ray below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lung abscess:

  • The given image shows an abscess cavity with an air-fluid level. The clinical presentation and the x-ray findings suggest a lung abscess.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pneumothorax: It will appear black on X-ray.

Option C - Pleural effusion: In the PA view, the fluid starts accumulating in the costophrenic angle (dependent part). So, blunting of the costophrenic angle is present.

Option D - Pericardial effusion: Pericardial effusion will show water bottle configuration.

questions.text: A patient complains of difficulty breathing, and fatigue. On examination, distended neck veins and muffled heart sounds were found. X-ray is shown below. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Constrictive pericarditis

Explanation:

  • The X-Ray image is suggestive of Constrictive pericarditis and the clinical features are also consistent with Constrictive pericarditis.
  • It is a condition in which granulation tissue formation in the pericardium results in loss of pericardial elasticity leading to restriction in the ventricular filling
  • X-ray appearance: Egg in cup appearance
  • IOC: CT scan

Constrictive Pericarditis:

Pathophysiology:

  • Progressive thickening, fibrosis, and calcification of the pericardium restrict heart filling.
  • Calcification can extend into the myocardium, impairing myocardial contraction.
  • Restricted ventricular filling leads to elevated atrial pressures, causing:
    • Atrial hypertrophy
    • Atrial dilation
    • Atrial fibrillation (common).
  • Primarily manifests as systemic venous congestion (lung congestion is rare).

Examination Findings:

Finding

Description

Elevated JVP with rapid y descent

Reflects rapid early diastolic filling of the right ventricle due to pressure gradient.

Fatigue

Caused by the heart’s inability to meet circulatory demands.

Rapid, low-volume pulse

Restricted filling limits stroke volume, weakening the pulse.

Pericardial knock

A loud early S3 from the thickened pericardium during diastolic filling.

Kussmaul’s sign

Paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration.

Hepatomegaly

Liver enlargement due to increased venous pressure.

Ascites

Abdominal fluid accumulation due to systemic venous congestion.

Peripheral oedema

Swelling in the extremities from fluid retention.

Pulsus paradoxus

A fall in systolic BP (10mm Hg) during inspiration, potentially impalpable pulse.

Atrial fibrillation

Common due to atrial hypertrophy and dilation.

 

Investigations:

Investigation

Purpose/Details

Chest X-ray
  • Egg in a cup appearance
  • Detects pericardial calcification, a key diagnostic clue.

Echocardiography

Visualises thickened pericardium and assesses cardiac function.

CT scanning

Helps in visualising pericardial calcification.

Complex echo-Doppler and cardiac catheterisation

  • Square root wave sign
  • Used to differentiate constrictive pericarditis from restrictive cardiomyopathy when diagnosis is uncertain.

 

Management:

Management Type

Treatment

Purpose/Details

Medical Management

Diuretics (e.g., loop diuretics, spironolactone)

Helps manage diastolic heart failure by reducing fluid overload.

Surgical Management

Pericardiectomy

 

Definitive treatment through surgical removal of the diseased pericardium. Significant improvement is possible, but the procedure has high complication risk and suboptimal outcomes in up to 50% of patients.

Bronchial asthma (Option B): This can present as pulmonary hyperinflation, bronchial wall thickening and peribronchial cuffing

Acute pericarditis (Option C): A flask shaped, enlarged cardiac silhouette will be observed in this condition.

Atrial myxoma (Option D): This can present with cardiomegaly, left atrial enlargement, vascular redistribution, prominent pulmonary trunk

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with a history of low-grade fever and cough. Based on the provided Chest X-ray image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Miliary TB

Explanation:

  • Miliary mottling refers to opacities that resemble millet seeds and are seen in the above Chest X-ray, which are seen in miliary TB (not specific)
  • It can also be seen in metastasis, pulmonary hemosiderosis, or silicosis.

 

Miliary tuberculosis (TB):

  • Severe and disseminated form of tuberculosis (TB), a condition arising from Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.
  • Results from hematogenous spread of the infection.
  • It can occur in both primary and post-primary pulmonary TB (PTB).
  • Clinically significant miliary TB affects 1% to 7% of all TB cases.
  • Initial chest X-ray (CXR) may appear normal; hyperinflation can be the earliest sign.
  • Typical radiographic findings:
    • Small, discrete nodules measuring 1-2 mm in diameter, distributed evenly throughout both lungs.
    • Tree-in-bud nodules are poorly defined and have a patchy distribution.
  • Chest CT: More sensitive than radiographs and reveals a random distribution of miliary nodules.
  • These nodules may enlarge and coalesce, forming focal or diffuse consolidation.
  • They resolve slowly over 2-6 months with adequate treatment, typically without causing scarring or calcification.
  • Miliary nodules signify active infection and are associated with a poor prognosis.

 

Lung cancer (Option A): Typically presents as a solitary nodule or mass, not diffuse tiny nodules.

 

ARDS (Option C): This would show bilateral diffuse alveolar infiltrates, not miliary nodules.

 

Aspergilloma (Option D): Usually seen as a solid mass (fungus ball) in a pre-existing cavity, not diffuse nodules. A radiologic finding is the air crescent sign, a crescent-shaped radiolucency representing air surrounding the fungus ball within the cavity.

questions.text: A patient who has been treated for TB in the past now presented with hemoptysis. Make a diagnosis based on the given X-ray.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aspergilloma
 

Explanation:

  • The above image shows the air crescent sign or the monod sign and along with the clinical presentation of the patient suggests aspergilloma.
  • Aspergilloma is seen in conditions with pre-existing lung cavities, such as Tuberculosis.

 

Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA)

 

  • ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction affecting the major upper lobe airways leading to upper lobe bronchiectasis.
  • It is associated with Elevated serum IgE levels, Positive serum precipitins for Aspergillus, Respiratory symptoms similar to asthma, Skin reactivity to Aspergillus

 

Radiographic Findings:

  • Non-segmental opacities primarily in the upper lobes
  • Lobar collapse
  • Branching thick tubular opacities due to mucus and fungus (known as the "finger-in-glove sign" or "Y" shape)
  • Occasional pulmonary cavitation

Aspergillus Mycetomas/ Aspergilloma/ Fungal Ball

 

  • Aspergillus mycetomas are saprophytic growths that inhabit preexisting lung cavities,
  • These are predominantly found in the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes.

 

CT Characteristics:

  • Appears as a mass with soft-tissue attenuation within a lung cavity.
  • The mass is usually separated from the cavity wall by an airspace, known as the "Air crescent" or Monod sign.
  • The position of the mass may change between prone and supine orientations, demonstrating its mobility.

Angioinvasive Aspergillosis

Fig: Halo sign

 

  • Primarily occurs in immunocompromised individuals,
  • Involves invasion and blockage of small to medium pulmonary arteries.
  • Leads to the formation of necrotic hemorrhagic nodules or infarcts.

 

CT Findings:

  • Commonly presented as multiple nodules surrounded by a halo of ground-glass attenuation "halo sign" or pleural-based wedge-shaped consolidations. (Option A)
  • The bronchial cut-off sign indicates central necrosis.
  • Nodular opacities tend to be widespread across several lung lobes, unlike the clustered peribronchial opacities seen in bacterial infections.

 

Bronchogenic carcinoma (Option A):

  • Typically appears as a mass or nodule, often without the "fungus ball" appearance.
  • Hemoptysis can occur, but a history of TB and cavity formation points more to aspergilloma.

 

Hydatid cyst (Option C): Seen in echinococcosis, it presents as a well-defined cystic lesion, sometimes with the "water-lily sign," not a mobile fungus ball.

 

 

 

Lung abscess (Option D): Appears as a cavity with an air-fluid level, not a distinct fungus ball.

questions.text: A child presents with cyanosis. His chest radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Explanation:

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF): The "boot-shaped heart" (coeur en sabot) seen on a chest radiograph is a classic finding in TOF. It occurs due to:

  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH), which causes the apex of the heart to lift upward.
  • Pulmonary artery hypoplasia or stenosis, which accentuates the shape.
    TOF is the most common cyanotic congenital heart defect, characterised by the four features:
  1. Pulmonary stenosis
  2. Right ventricular hypertrophy
  3. Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  4. Overriding aorta

Chest X-ray Imaging in TOF:

  • The classic finding on a chest X-ray for TOF is the “boot-shaped” heart (also known as coeur en sabot), caused by right ventricular hypertrophy leading to an upward tilt of the cardiac apex. There is often a concave main pulmonary artery and decreased pulmonary vascular markings, reflecting the reduced blood flow through the pulmonary arteries due to the RVOT obstruction.
  • Some patients may also present with a right-sided aortic arch, which can be identified on the X-ray.

 

 

Ebstein’s anomaly (option B): This is incorrect because the radiographic finding in Ebstein’s anomaly is an enlarged, "box-shaped" heart due to massive right atrial enlargement, not a boot shape.

 

Transposition of great arteries (TGA) (option C): This is incorrect because TGA typically shows an "egg-on-string" appearance on chest X-ray, with a narrow mediastinum.


Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC) (option D): This is incorrect because TAPVC commonly shows a "snowman" or "figure-of-eight" sign due to dilated veins and a vertical vein, not a boot-shaped heart.

questions.text: Hamman sign is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pneumomediastinum

Explanation:

Pneumomediastinum:

  • Hamman sign is a characteristic physical finding heard on auscultation. It is described as a crunching sound or synchronous clicking sound with the heartbeat, often heard in the precordial area.
  • It is typically associated with pneumomediastinum, where air is present in the mediastinal space, often due to esophageal rupture or trauma. The air in the mediastinum creates a distinctive sound when it moves with the heartbeats, producing the Hamman sign.

Pneumomediastinum:

  • Presence of free air around mediastinal structures.
  • Common Causes:
    • Blunt or penetrating trauma.
    • Esophageal perforation.
    • Recent interventions in the esophageal or tracheobronchial tree.
    • Pulmonary infections.
    • Gas-forming infections in the mediastinum.
    • Cocaine inhalation.
    • Extension of air from a pneumothorax.
  • Hamman's crunch sign: Unusual, adventitious sound heard on auscultation of the chest.
  • Radiographic Signs:
    • Ring around the artery sign: Air around the pulmonary artery (usually the right) outlining the artery.
  • Sail sign: Elevation of the thymus caused by air.
  • Continuous diaphragm sign: Air trapped posterior to the pericardium, appearing as a continuous air collection on an AP projection
  • Tubular artery sign: Air outlines the medial side of major aortic branches, with aerated lung outlining the lateral side.
  • Double bronchial wall sign: Air adjacent to the bronchus highlights the bronchial wall.
  • Naclerio V-sign: V-shaped air lucency in the left lower mediastinal area.

 

Pneumoperitoneum (option A): Incorrect because pneumoperitoneum refers to air in the peritoneal cavity, usually caused by gastrointestinal perforation. It does not typically produce the Hamman sign. Instead, it is more commonly detected through radiological imaging (e.g., abdominal X-ray) showing air under the diaphragm.

Pneumopericardium (option B): Incorrect because pneumopericardium is the presence of air in the pericardial sac around the heart, which may lead to cardiac tamponade. While it can cause a clinical presentation of chest pain or dyspnoea, it is not typically associated with the Hamman sign.

Hydropneumothorax (option D): Incorrect because hydropneumothorax refers to the accumulation of both air and fluid in the pleural cavity, commonly due to trauma or infection. While it may cause dyspnoea and chest pain, it does not produce the characteristic Hamman sign.

questions.text: Please identify the rib that is shown in the X-ray.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 3rd rib posterior part

Explanation:

3rd rib posterior part:

  • The posterior part of the rib is typically identified by its position relative to the spine and the more horizontal orientation in an X-ray, especially when taken from a lateral view.
  • The posterior part of the rib will be closer to the vertebrae and typically appears more curved and parallel to the spine on the X-ray.
  • The highlighted structure in the image is consistent with this description, which is why the 3rd rib posterior part is the correct answer.

 

3rd rib anterior part (option A): Incorrect because the anterior part of the 3rd rib would be closer to the sternum, with a more forward and downward orientation on an X-ray. The posterior part is more visible in this case.

4th rib anterior part (option C): Incorrect because the 4th rib would be located further down than the 3rd rib, and its anterior part would be closer to the sternum. This option doesn't match the positioning seen in the image.

1st rib anterior part (option D): Incorrect because the 1st rib is positioned more superiorly, closer to the clavicle. Its anterior part would be located near the sternum, and this is not consistent with the rib shown in the image.

questions.text: A child presents with breathlessness. On chest x-ray, the following object is seen. Identify the object.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Button battery

Explanation:

  • Button batteries, particularly when ingested or aspirated by children, are a serious medical emergency.
  • On chest X-ray, a button battery typically appears as a circular object with a characteristic double ring sign (due to the metal casing and the central core).
  • If lodged in the airways or gastrointestinal tract, it can lead to severe complications such as mucosal damage, chemical burns, or even perforation.
  • This is a well-known radiological finding in pediatric cases.

Radiological Features of Foreign Body Ingestion

Foreign Body

AP View

Lateral View

Key Feature

Coin in Esophagus

Circular opacity

Slit-like appearance

Common in children, lodges at cricopharyngeal junction

Coin in Trachea

Slit-like appearance

Circular opacity

High risk of airway obstruction

Button Battery in Esophagus

Circular opacity with halo sign

Double contour ring

Can cause tissue necrosis, urgent removal needed

 

Coin (Option B): While a coin may appear on chest X-ray and be ingested or aspirated, it lacks the characteristic double ring appearance of a button battery. Coin ingestion can also cause blockage or discomfort but is less dangerous in comparison to button batteries.

Ball (Option C): Balls, especially small ones, can be ingested or aspirated, but they typically don't present with the distinct radiological appearance that button batteries do. Balls might also be seen on X-ray but lack the same level of concern for chemical or electrical burns.

Bottle cap (Option D): Bottle caps can be ingested or aspirated as well, but they do not present with the specific double ring sign of a button battery. While they can cause obstruction, they are generally less hazardous than button batteries.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not a potential cause for the radiological finding shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Foreign body

Explanation:

  • The foreign body does not intrinsically cause a white-out hemithorax; it may lead to secondary effects (e.g., collapse), which would then result in the finding. However, as an independent cause, it is not directly responsible.

 

Whiteout hemithorax/Opacified hemithorax

Blackout hemithorax/Hyperlucent hemithorax

  • This refers to when there is complete opacification of an entire hemithorax.
  • Clinical information and other radiological findings are important to make a definite diagnosis.
  • This refers to an entire hyperlucent hemithorax.
  • It results from various congenital and acquired conditions of the pulmonary parenchyma, airway, pulmonary vasculature, pleural space, and chest wall.

Differential diagnoses

Differential diagnoses

  • Atelectasis of the entire lung
  • Large pleural effusion (Option C)
  • Pneumonia of the entire lung
  • Postpneumonectomy appearance
  • Large pulmonary, pleural, or chest wall mass in diseases like Ewing sarcoma, mesothelioma
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia or agenesis
  • Consolidation (Option A)
  • Collapse (Option B)
  • Radiologic technique errors
  • Emphysema (bullous emphysema)
  • Asymmetric chest wall soft tissue due to conditions like:
    • Poland syndrome
    • Unilateral mastectomy
    • Some professions like butchers, carpenters, etc
  • Atrophy of trapezius muscle after radical neck dissection
  • Extrapulmonary air collection in pneumothorax and subcutaneous emphysema
  • Contralateral large pleural effusion (Pseudo hyperlucent appearance of opposite lung)
  • Bronchial obstruction
    • Foreign body in children
    • Bronchial atresia
    • Endobronchial tumor
    • Broncholith
  • Bronchiolitis obliterans in Swyer-James syndrome
  • Congenital lobar hyperinflation
  • Conditions affecting pulmonary vessels:
    • Pulmonary agenesis or hypoplasia
    • Proximal interruption of pulmonary artery
    • Massive central pulmonary embolism (PE) leading to oligemia

questions.text: The patient has a history of fever and cough for the last 5 days. The examination findings show crepitations, and a chest X-ray is shown below. Based on these details, what is the likely diagnosis for this patient?

choices.text: Apical segment of Right lower lobe consolidation
Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Right middle lobe consolidation

Explanation:

  • The X-ray image shows a well-defined opacity in the right middle lobe, which is consistent with the description of pneumonia in the scenario. The loss of the right heart border indicates pathology in the right middle lobe or medial right lower lobe.
  • Pneumonia is typically associated with fever, cough, and crepitations on examination, which match the clinical picture given in this question.
  • The loss of clear demarcation between the surrounding structures and normal lung is called silhouette sign.

Lobar Localization:

  • Lateral radiograph: Right and left upper lobe bronchi can be seen as two circular radiolucent areas with the right above the left.
  • PA view of the chest: Can locate any structure in the superoinferior dimension as well as the mediolateral dimension.
  • Silhouette sign: Locate any structure in the posteroanterior dimension.
  • Left Lung: Only has an oblique fissure, separating the left upper (LUL) and lower (LLL) lobes.
  • Right Lung: Oblique and horizontal fissures separate the right lung's 3 lobes.
    • Oblique fissure divides the RML and RLL.
    • Horizontal fissure divides the RUL and RML.

 

Silhouette Sign:

  • Absence of the depiction of an anatomic soft-tissue border.
  • Produced by an intrathoracic abnormality that touches the borders of the heart or aorta and obliterates those borders on the frontal chest radiograph.
  • The sign actually refers to the absence of a silhouette.
  • Silhouette sign helps localize airspace opacities, atelectasis, or masses in the lung.
  • Loss of normal silhouettes on frontal chest radiographs indicates the site of pathology:
    • Right paratracheal stripe: Right upper lobe
    • Right heart border: Right middle lobe or medial right lower lobe (Option B)
    • Right hemidiaphragm: Right lower lobe
    • Aortic knuckle: Left upper lobe
    • Left heart border: Lingular segments of the left upper lobe
    • Left hemidiaphragm or descending aorta: Left lower lobe

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the CT scan shown below:
questions.solution:
Correction Option C: Superior vena cava

  • The marked structure corresponds to the superior vena cava
  • The superior vena cava is a large vein that returns deoxygenated blood from the upper body to the right atrium of the heart.
  • It is located in the upper part of the chest and is typically visible on a CT scan.

Other options

Option A: Descending aorta- This option is incorrect

Option B: Ascending aorta- This option is incorrect

Option D: Right pulmonary artery- This option is incorrect

questions.text: What is the subject matter of the X-ray image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • The X-ray is suggestive of pleural effusion. The given chest X-ray shows obliteration of the left costophrenic angle with a wide pleural-based dome-shaped opacity projecting into the lung noted tracking along the CP angle and lateral chest wall.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tension Pneumothorax: It has air filling in the pleural cavity causing compression over lung parenchyma resulting in a Visceral pleural line sign which is not seen in the above image. Hence, an incorrect choice.

Option B - Emphysema: It would show air trapping along with hyperinflation of alveoli resulting in decreased opacity and increased translucency with hyper-inflated lungs, which is not seen in the above image. Hence, an incorrect choice.

Option D - Bronchiectasis: It is associated with a signet ring sign along with dilated central and peripheral airways, which is not seen in the above image. Hence, an incorrect choice.

questions.text: Pick out the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Cervical rib:

  • A cervical rib is an extra rib that develops above the first rib in the neck region. It is a congenital anomaly and occurs in a small percentage of the population. A cervical rib can potentially compress nearby structures, such as nerves or blood vessels, leading to various symptoms including neck pain, shoulder pain, arm pain, and numbness or weakness in the affected arm. The presence of a cervical rib can be evaluated using imaging studies like X-rays or CT scans.

Incorrect Options:  

Option A. Costochondritis:

  • Costochondritis refers to the inflammation of the cartilage that connects the ribs to the sternum (breastbone). It typically causes localized chest pain and tenderness, which may worsen with movement or deep breathing. The pain is often sharp and can be mistaken for a heart-related condition. However, costochondritis does not involve any structural abnormalities of the ribs or vertebral column.

Option B. Spondylolisthesis:

  • Spondylolisthesis is a condition in which one vertebra slips forward over the vertebra below it. It commonly occurs in the lumbar spine (lower back) and can result in lower back pain, radiating leg pain, and neurologic symptoms if nerve compression occurs. It does not specifically involve the ribs or the presence of a cervical rib.

Option D. Rib fracture:

  • A rib fracture refers to a break or cracks in one or more of the ribs. It typically occurs due to trauma or direct impact on the chest. Rib fractures can cause localized chest pain that worsens with deep breathing, coughing, or movement. Diagnosis is usually confirmed through imaging, such as an X-ray or CT scan, which may reveal the fracture line or displacement of the fractured rib.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male patient presented with complaints of fever and cough. His chest radiograph shows an air bronchogram sign. The probable diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Consolidation

  • Air bronchogram is a radiologic sign where air-filled bronchi are made visible by the surrounding consolidated alveoli (which are fluid- or pus-filled).

  • This occurs when the alveoli are opacified (e.g., with pus, fluid, or blood), but the bronchi remain air-filled, creating the appearance of branching lucent structures within a dense opacity.

Air Bronchogram Sign and Chest Radiographic Diagnosis

Feature Air Bronchogram Sign
Definition Lucent air-filled bronchi visible against consolidated lung
Seen in Consolidation, pulmonary edema, ARDS, some tumors
Absent in Pleural effusion, atelectasis with bronchial obstruction
Most classical cause Lobar pneumonia (consolidation)

Pleural effusion (Option A):
Incorrect because effusion occurs in the pleural space, and the fluid obscures lung markings and airways, making air bronchograms absent.

Hilar lymphadenopathy (Option C):
Incorrect because lymphadenopathy causes mass-like opacities in the hilum, not diffuse alveolar filling, so no air bronchogram is seen.

Bronchiectasis (Option D):
Incorrect because bronchiectasis involves dilated bronchi, not alveolar filling. It may show a "tram-track" appearance but not air bronchograms.

questions.text: Based on the provided X-ray, identify the likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C.

  • Pneumoperitoneum: Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of air or gas within the peritoneal cavity, which is the space within the abdomen that contains organs such as the stomach, intestines, and liver. On an X-ray, the pneumoperitoneum may appear as air under the diaphragm or a distinct "free air" sign. It is often associated with conditions such as perforated viscus (e.g., perforated bowel) or abdominal trauma.

incorrect Options:

Option A. Subdiaphragmatic abscess: A subdiaphragmatic abscess refers to an infection or collection of pus located below the diaphragm, usually in the abdominal cavity. It is typically not visualized on a standard chest X-ray and may require additional imaging modalities such as ultrasound or CT scan for diagnosis.

Option B. Pneumothorax: Pneumothorax is the presence of air or gas in the pleural cavity, the space between the lungs and the chest wall. It can be seen on a chest X-ray as a dark area with collapsed lung tissue. However, without seeing the actual X-ray, it is difficult to determine if this is the correct diagnosis.

Option D. Intestinal obstruction: Intestinal obstruction occurs when there is a blockage in the normal flow of the intestinal contents. It can be caused by various factors such as adhesions, hernias, tumors, or volvulus. On an X-ray, findings may include dilated bowel loops and air-fluid levels, although the specific features depend on the location and cause of the obstruction.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a 74-year-old man, who comes to the outpatient department (OPD) with a history of substantial unintentional weight loss, lack of appetite, and iron deficiency anemia, after a chest x-ray was performed and the results are provided below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • Given X-ray image is suggestive of Cannon Ball Metastasis to the Lungs. This can be seen in different types of malignancies. Cannonball Metastasis is seen in choriocarcinoma because of the rich vascular supply, due to which metastasis occurs via the vascular route to the lungs.
  • These cannonball metastases appear on chest X-rays as multiple white opacities like the fire of cannonballs. All these white opacities represent metastatic deposits.
  • White opacities are clearly observed in the given X-ray, indicating option c as the correct choice.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A: Bronchogenic Carcinoma is associated with increased vascularity and mass in the lung that may abut the vessels, and it may be associated with central necrosis and cavitation. It can also be associated with hypercalcemia and calcification deposits in the lungs. So, the X-ray shows central necrosis, cavitation, and hypercalcemia in a patient, which is not observed in the given case. Therefore, option A is an incorrect choice.

Option B: Mesothelioma is associated with pleural plaques and deposits over pleura, which is not seen in the given X-rays, making it an incorrect choice. 

Option D: Pneumoconiosis is seen in X-rays in different patterns depending upon the type of pneumoconiosis. For example, in asbestosis, multiple pleural plaques are observed. Coal worker pneumoconiosis can present with emphysema, multiple pneumoconiotic changes, and hyperinflation. All these changes are not seen in the given x-ray. Thus, option d is incorrect.

questions.text: For the diagnosis of all lung carcinomas, a thorax CECT is necessary. However, in which of the following scenarios is MRI considered beneficial?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option is D. Pancoast tumor.

Pancoast tumor, also known as superior sulcus tumor, is a type of lung cancer that occurs in the upper part of the lung, typically involving the lung apex, adjacent chest wall, and nearby structures. This type of tumor is often associated with specific symptoms such as shoulder pain, arm weakness, and Horner's syndrome (a group of symptoms caused by damage to the sympathetic nerves).

In the case of Pancoast tumor, MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) is useful for evaluation and diagnosis. MRI provides detailed images of soft tissues and can help visualize the extent of tumor involvement in the chest wall, surrounding structures, and nerves.
